Posts.Content: On 10/15/2009 Maryann1128 wrote: I have been given different answers to this question.  I believe that since everything is gone, a mammogram is not needed.  My surgeon says to get one but I feel they just want to cover themselves.  It is upsetting to me to even think about going to a center, explaining I had breast cancer, and knowing the technician may not know how to react. I appreciate your support and feedback :)The technicians have seen everything---no worries there.  Their job is to be as supportive of you as possible.  I had a single mastectomy and have to get a mammo & ultrasound of the other side yearly.  But if you've had a bilateral and have not had reconstruction what is there to put in the machine? ;>)  The other writer is correct in that an MRI will be more sensitive and pick up more.  It also is not perfect--there are false positives.  So do some research on your options, your chances of recurrence, and talk to your drs to get enough info for you to make an informed decision. I wish you all the best.
Posts.Title: Mammogram after bilat mast?

Posts.Content: On 10/5/2009 vee345 wrote: My friend had her first chemotherapy session today, and since she's gotten home, she's had severe nausea and vomiting. From everything I've read and heard, it isn't normal to be this sick after the first time. She's on cytoxan and taxotere. If anyone has any idea on why she's getting so sick or any tips to help with the nausea, we would really appreciate it. It's tough to see her feel so bad. Thanks and God bless, Vee Her oncologist should have prescribed some anti-nausea drugs for her. Everyone reacts differently to the drugs but she should definitely call her dr and tell what's going on.  Sometimes folks think they shouldn't "bother" the dr.---well, phooey! They're getting paid big bucks and if you're vomiting they have the means to help you!  Call!  Also she should be eating very bland food--nothing spicey.
Posts.Title: Nausea and vomiting on the first day?

Posts.Content: You might want to look into the possibility of having a patient advocate.  Your treatment center may have them or you may want to search for one on the Web.  If there's a Wellness Center nearby they may be able to point you in the right direction.  I went to a talk given by a patient advocate at the Wellness Center near me.  Also read about them.  It really does sound like you're getting a run around.  Hooray for you for standing up for yourself and switching oncologists!  A suggestion:  take a look at the latest issue of More magazine.  There's an excellent article in there on how to choose a doctor based on your and their communication style.  It'll help you assess what you need from the medical professionals.   I agree about getting copies of all your records.  That way you can read them yourself (you may find yourself looking up terms online---I know I did), you'll have all the info about your treatments in one place (good thing for the future) and you can bring up questions about reports that you've read. Write your questions down ahead of time and leave space to write your answers.   Also don't be afraid to ask the doc to rephrase an answer if you don't understand it.  I remember saying once, "Can you put that in regular English instead of Medspeak?" I wish you all the best through your treatment journey.
Posts.Title: Breast-to-bone cancer

Posts.Content: You need to know that the medical community considers stage IV not curable but manageable.  They consider it to be a chronic condition.  There are stage IV survivors who live for many years.  That said, your friend's mental attitude will play a huge part in her health.  So the quotes are timely messages to pass on.  There are many excellent books to read.  Try Cancer As a Turning Point by Lawrence LeShan, Cancer: 50 Essential Things To Do by Greg Anderson, Bernie Seigel's books and Getting Well Again by O. Carl Simonton, et al. These are just some of the ones I found helpful.  I hope they'll be helpful for you & your friend. Blessings to you both.
Posts.Title: Need Information

Posts.Content: CALL your surgeon back and get these questions answered to your satisfaction!  You can certainly request "happy pills" (love that!) so that you will feel calm.  Also ask how long you're going to have to wait for the results (and decide how you want to hear them, i.e., over the phone or wait for an appt.)  Good luck to you, dear.
Posts.Title: Scared about breast biopsy

Posts.Content: On 9/5/2007 grannydiva wrote: i have had lumpectomy, very very small dot in lymph node, doctor wants me to do chemo,hormone and radiation, and said my recurrance is 35% and think about a mastectomy both breast,  i was all for the treatment but then in my reading and learning i find they use a scale of20% to 50% for recurrance, this would mean my 35% is not in my favor and is that why my onocologist suggested mastectomy? i am totalled confused what to do!  any suggestions,  i have stage 1 cancer Hi GrannyDiva, If you have not gotten a second opinion I would suggest you do that.  Have the drs. print out survival rates for someone your age with the stage and type of cancer you have (there's a website they have access to for this).  This should show you how many women survive if they do nothing, how many survive if they do chemo, etc.  Have the dr. carefully explain the numbers.  It's hard to hear all these percentages when your brain is spinning around in circles yelling "I have cancer!!!!"  So bring someone with you to the appointments who can listen carefully and ask questions too. I wish you all the best.
Posts.Title: recurrance

Posts.Content: Hi Jodie, When you go for your PET scan ask the tech how soon the dr. will have the report.  I would bet it's quicker than 8 days, in which case why not call the dr.'s office and ask for the results?  I agree, it's hard to wait on pins and needles to hear about an important test. Wishing you strength and perseverance on this journey.  I would also recommend the book Close to the Bone, life threatening illness as a soul journey by Jean Shinoda Bolen, MD.  It's helped and inspired me a lot.  Get the 2007 revised edition.  Blessings to you.
Posts.Title: finished with chemo for now...now what?

Posts.Content: Landed in the hospital w/high blood calcium levels and was diagnosed w/mets to the bone marrow (not bone).  Was put on Zometa and every month my pain level spikes enough to put me on pain meds for 2 weeks.  Not only that but the pain moves around--this month it hurts on both of my sides but not the back like the month before.  Anyone else experience this and what have you done for the pain?  Percocet only dulls it a bit for me, doesn't make it go away and it has its own unpleasant side effects.  This has been going on for 3 months now and I'm due for another infusion Sept. 1.
Posts.Title: Anyone have pain with Zometa?

Posts.Content: My chemo treatment was TAC once every 3 weeks for 18 weeks. I first had Neulasta because I didn't want to do the series of 7 shots of Neupogen (which meant driving to the hospital every day) but the feeling of being run over by a Mack truck and severe pain finally made me reconsider after the 3rd round of Neulasta. I was able to tolerate the Neupogen better, still some aches but not quite so severe or long lasting. I also saw a acupuncturist who helped with the neck pain. I didn't have any numbness. Bug your doc til you get some answers! They seem to forget that you'd like some quality of life while you're getting through this hell. Having a numb face wasn't part of what you signed up for! Hang in there. You'll make it through this.
Posts.Title: Neupogen Injections Numbness in Face

Posts.Content: Thanks Sue.  Just had infusion #4 on Weds. and am waiting to see what happens this weekend, which is when the pain usually kicks in.  So far things aren't too bad, just more tired than usual.  I took ibuprofen before treatment so we'll see.
Posts.Title: Anyone have pain with Zometa?

Posts.Content: On 1/28/2009 Sherri G wrote: Hi I had bil masectomy 3 years ago since then I have had about 4 different surgeries my concern is the pain my left arm and neck hurt a lot. I have seen surgent and oncologist. I had mentioned a couple of times that under the left arm it feels swollen and lot of pain in back of arm and neck my oncologist said have you ever heard of exercise ? I never had this before surgery and I 'm 5'3 154 pounds  Jan of 2008 after surgery they thought I was having a heart attack because the pain was so bad.  sherri     So Sherri, What, besides the smartass answer, did your doc do for your pain complaints?  Have you been evaluated for lymphedema (I ask because of the swelling you mention)?  Did they give you stretching exercises to do after surgery?  If you had radiation you need to do those stretching exercises for several years after completion.  Have they sent you to rehab?  Have you tried going to a cranio-sacral massage therapist for the neck pain?  Also myo-fascial release therapy may help with the pain too. I had a lot of neck/shoulder pain after surgery and did all of the above.  I'm no longer in pain, my lyphedema is improving and my mobility is much much better.  Ask your doctor for some referrals.  Hope this helps.
Posts.Title: left arm and chest pain

Posts.Content: Have a consult with a few reconstruction plastic surgeons (your dr. can refer you).  Consults will get you the info you need.  The reconstruction of the nipple wouldn't be as extensive as the previous description since you do not have to replace the entire breast, i.e., no expanders or implant.
Posts.Title: Nipple Removal

Posts.Content: Hope you will have the time to do some research because she does have options.  Go to Dr. Susan Love's website for starters.  There are different chemo drugs and they are given in different combinations and at different intervals.  I would HIGHLY suggest she also get a 2nd opinion (even if she likes her onco) just to confirm what the first dr. will recommend.  Get a list of the drugs her dr. recommends, also find out what will be recommended to combat the side effects (and read up on the side effects from those).  Investigate complementary treatments to go along with the chemo.  I received acupuncture during chemo and it helped with the nausea and bone pain from the Neulasta shots (those are given to boost white cell counts---find out if your Mom will be receiving those or Neupogen).  Your Mom is so lucky to have you to help her out during this.  The more you can learn about treatments the better able she will be to make informed decisions.  Just remember it is her decision and it may not always be the same thing you would have chosen.  She needs your support in whatever she decides. Blessings to you both.
Posts.Title: Mom going for chemo

Posts.Content: Hard to believe female body builders use Arimidex when it is linked to bone loss........  I agree that it has a lot of crappy side effects.  I too lost libido (after being thrown into menopause and having chemo & radiation).  I went to a gynocologist who specializes in menopause and female cancer patients.  She put me on vagifem first for the awful dryness and now I use the Estring.  Yes, it secretes a tiny amount of estrogen (and I had E++ cancer) but she says it's confined to the vaginal area and I also decided that quality of life was important to me.  My life has already been altered by the cancer treatment and resulting lymphedema.  I wasn't about to give up my sex life too.  Does the Estring put me back to where I was prior to cancer?  No, but it has helped both with sex (now possible)and with the bladder problems so I'm satisfied.
Posts.Title: Loss of libido after bi-lateral mastectomy and Arimidex

Posts.Content: On 3/28/2007 Tryingtoremain+ wrote: I was dx., with breast cancer in Sept., 2006..Under went 2 lumpectomy's & 33 radiation treatments which was completed on Jan., 11-2007.. Feel very lucky.. I currently take Arimidex.. I do notice hand & knee pain, increased hotflashes, fatigue, & unable to sleep.. I recently had a follow up ultrasound which showed  tissue thickening & fluid pocket..They now want me to have a breast MRI with fluid aspiration and possible tissue bx of thickened area. What am I to think?? Want to remain + yet worried.. Any one experience this? It seems with everything I have read no one seems to keen on Arimidex.. Plz talk to me would like to learn as much as I can... Thank u & my thoughts are with u.. Deb Hi Deb, Don't hesitate to closely question your dr. about this current condition.  Sometimes something they see as routine does not appear that way to the patient.  I had a mastectomy so cannot speak directly to your first question but can tell you that I just started Arimidex about 1 1/2 wks ago.  I am more tired and a bit achey---typical side effects.  I will continue to take it because the statistics show that for me and my kind of cancer (invasive lobular, stage 3A with 16 nodes involved), it gives me a greater chance of being alive in 10 yrs.  From all I've read, it seems Arimidex affects different women in different ways.  Check out bcaction.org and their report on aromatase inhibitor side effects.  They've arranged the data according to the age of the respondents,the reported side effects, the perceived severity of the side effect, and noted other side effects that were reported by less than 1% of the women who responded to the study.  Kinda lets you know what to expect. Also there are 3 different kinds of aromatase inhibitors so if one gives you severe side effects you can try another.  My dr. said if side effects are severe for me I could stop for a month and then restart because usually the side effects are less severe after restarting. Keep in touch here.  There's tremendous support from everyone.  I hope everything goes well for you.
Posts.Title: Hi Everyone - New here

Posts.Content: On 8/28/2007 Sherryk wrote: Today my doctor started me on Femara(Letrozole).2.5mg once a day. I have elected NOT to have breast surgery and my cancer is ER/PR positive3+/4. I have never heard of this drug. Is anyone out there taking this drug an does anyone know of the  problems if any. I was told the cancer is lying on the prectus and rib cage. I have a bad heart so surgery is our for me. Any info gals? I sure would appricate it. Blessings,sherryk. Femara is an aromatase inhibitor drug (as are Arimidex and Aromasin), which basically means it prevents your body from producing estrogen.  Side effects seem to vary according to age and health status.  Some of the most common are weight gain, arthritis-like symptoms, joint and bone pain, and hot flashes.  Breast Cancer Action did a survey of women on aromatase inhibitors and listed their side effects and the severity of them according to the drug and age of the patient.  Check out their website to see the whole thing:  www.bcaction.org Hope this helps.
Posts.Title: New Drug Info please

Posts.Content: I had lobular BC in 06, stage 3 which means it was over 5 cm and had lymph node involvement.  I would advise at least a 2nd opinion and not rushing into surgery.  She does have time despite the hysteria of the docs.  Use the time to find out her various options for treatment.  For instance, she may want to talk to a plastic surgeon about what can be done if a partial (? not sure what that means) mastectomy is to be done.  One thing she can do right now is change her diet--eliminate sugar, eliminate white bread, eliminate alcohol and start eating LOTS of veggies, both lightly cooked and raw.  If she is able to see a nutritionist who works w/cancer patients that would be very helpful. If cancer is found in the sentinel node biopsy they will then proceed to do the axillary dissection right then.  Radiation would come after pathology. I had chemo lst, then radiation. If she wants to know if it has spread to other organs, it's better to have a thermogram done. This picks up changes sooner than CT scans.  Generally you can find a chiropractor or a naturopathic doc who offers thermography. Above all remember, and remind her, that it is HER decision what kind and how much treatment she chooses to have.  You've come to a very helpful place here which can help you both research her options. blessings to you both.
Posts.Title: 64YO Mother DX Lobular BC (Advice?)

Posts.Content: Ask the hospitals.  Also check for micro-surgeons (they would also do surgery like hand surgery).  You want to look for someone experienced, who's done this many times.  Maybe there's a national group these drs. belong to?
Posts.Title: DIEP

Posts.Content: They should be offering you prescription cream, Silvadreme I think it's called.
Posts.Title: Skin burning

Posts.Content: People respond differently to the AI's.  You won't necessarily have all the side effects.  Also if you have intolerable side effects with one, you have the option of switching to another, which may work better for you.  Something my doctor said is feasible (I start Arimidex next month) is to stop briefly to alleviate the side effects, then start again.  He said usually the side effects are less or not there (he's not talking about possible bone loss, obviously). About your neuropathy:  my friend also has painful neuropathy and her dr. put her on a pain med. (sorry I don't remember the name of it)  Have you told your dr. how painful the neuropathy is?  I hope you have talked about your fears about the side effects of the AI's with your dr., too.  He/she may have info you haven't heard.  I do understand how you feel.  I would not be starting Arimidex except for the fact that the statistics show I will have a much greater chance of survival, (I was diagnosed Stage 3A in 4/06), so I've decided I'll deal with the side effects if at all possible.  Ultimately we all have to remember that each of us is truly in charge of our own treatment and we can decide what we want to take, evaluate how any side effects impact our quality of life and whether we want to deal with them, add up the pros and cons and decide from there.
Posts.Title: arimidex verse famara

Posts.Content: I'd like to suggest you look into massage therapy,  I see a cranio-sacral massage therapist who also does myo-fascial release work on me.  Helped with pain and range of motion.  I was very clear about when anything hurt too much, esp, pulling on my radiated skin, so treatment probably went a bit slower but it's definitely been worth it.  There are other body work therapies out there also---see what's available in your area.  Hope this helps!
Posts.Title: help for pain after a masectomy

Posts.Content: p.s.  How's your diet and are you taking supplements to help you recuperate?  It all helps.
Posts.Title: help for pain after a masectomy

Posts.Content: Has anyone tried acupuncture for their bone pain/aches from the Arimidex?  I had acupuncture during chemo--helped with nausea, energy AND the awful bone pain from the Neulasta/Neupogen shots.  I am due to start an AI and I'm really not sure I want to except the statistics show I'll live longer.  Still trying to balance quality of life issues so I can understand how you're feeling.  My quality of life has already been affected by neuropathy of hands and feet due to chemo and lymphedema of arm & hand due to 24 lymphnodes removed.  They can't really tell me if either condition will improve.
Posts.Title: arimidex~side effects

Posts.Content: On 2/19/2008 earthstar wrote: I had a lumpectomy early in November, followed by 10 sessions of brachytherapy with a Mammosite catheter. Everything went smoothly. Now I have developed some edema in the same breast. My doc also says we'll watch it. It's not uncomfortable yet, but will a sports bra keep it from getting worse? Does activity (raking, working out) make it better or worse? Thanks for being there. Hi Earthstar, Having lymphedema in my left arm & hand and somewhat in the shoulder, chest and left side after a left mastectomy and axillary dissection (24 nodes removed), I have a couple of suggestions.  My lymphedema started during chemo and wasn't properly taken care of initially (partly because the first therapist I saw wasn't good and partly because I was in denial so didn't go when I should have) which meant it progressed to stage 2.  I went through CDT (complete decongestive therapy) twice, both during and after radiation (radiation makes you swell).  I now wear a custom one piece sleeve/glove every day except to sleep and perform MLD (manual lymphatic drainage) every night.  My lymphedema is under control but took many months to get there.  All this is to serve as a heads up to you and anyone else with swelling. Suggestion 1:  Don't just "watch" it and don't assume your doctor knows everything about lymphedema.  Insist your dr. refer you to a lymphedema therapist----that would be a physical therapist trained in lymphedema therapy (preferably Vodder trained--that's the gold standard).  You can suggest to your dr. that it's for preventive therapy. That therapist will assess your edema, perform MLD on you, instruct you how to do it, and make any needed recommendations on proper garments for control.  If you treat lymphedema early (stage 1) it goes away and you then are informed about precautions to prevent recurrence. Suggestion 2:  If you prefer to "watch" it, then I'd say a sports bra (well-fitted, NOT tight!!!  Too tight will make it worse by cutting off drainage) could be helpful. Better you should be fitted by someone trained in fitting lymphedema garments----they can give you good recommendations about what works. Suggestion 3:  Activity does help control swelling.  The trick is not to overdo it because that can make it worse.  If you were an active person before cancer don't think you can immediately go back and do what you did at the same level---start at a low level for a short amount of time and see how you feel and what the effects are.  I would not resume playing tennis, paint a room, or do strenuous weight training until the swelling is resolved---particularly if the affected side is your dominant side. Suggestion 4:  Check out the National Lymphedema Network website---there is LOTS of helpful info there and a list of precautions. Good luck!
Posts.Title: lymphedema

Posts.Content: On 7/25/2007 katty_2007 wrote: hi!   I'm mila,female,25 years old, indonesia. i had mastectomy at the right side 2 years ago.i had done the operation at singapore. i had chemoteraphy and radiation. i had 6 packets chemoteraphy, each chemoteraphy include 3 times chemotheraphy,so the total of chemoteraphy is 18 times and 30 times of radiation. my problem now is after the chemoteraphy done, my ca maker is going up again.I dont know what happen.Everyday I had a glass of juice(apple, carrot, n bitroot) and much of supplement. i done my chemoteraphy a year ago. and now the doctor said that i should take chemoteraphy again.but i dont want it.i want look the other opinion, coz i know that the chemo isn't good to my body. Now i had backpain too. friend can you help me?what should i do?     Hi Katty, I assume when you write your ca marker is going up that this is a blood test you're talking about.  I've been told that when those markers go up it can mean cancer but it can also mean other things.  Have you had any other tests, like an MRI or PET/CT scan, to prove the cancer has returned?  You should certainly look into that before deciding on any treatment. I wish you well.
Posts.Title: ca maker is going up again after chemoteraphy done

Posts.Content: I agree with those that said the first needle biopsy is the worst.  The supposed lidocaine or whatever numbing agent they used was worthless.  The needle for a core biopsy is a large gauge and then they push in those markers!!  That burned for me and at that point I started to cry.  I am pretty tough but that was the day I found out I had cancer and was immediately sent to get the biopsy, so to have all that pain was pretty traumatizing.  I totally sympathize with you.  Five days later I was in surgery for a modified radical mastectomy.  I wasn't told either about having to get a shot right behind the nipple for the blue dye.  I looked at the tech like he was NUTS!  I let him know that if it hurt he was stopping and giving me something for the pain.  However the needle for that is much smaller than for the biopsy so it wasn't nearly as bad.  So please hang in there, you can do this for yourself.  And, as previously said, tell the staff how you're feeling and that you need support through this, whether that be a hand to hold or a sedative!
Posts.Title: Coping with fear and anxiety

Posts.Content: I was started on Arimidex 3/07 and joint pain, trigger fingers, etc started a few months after.  Walking, getting up after sitting was so painful.  I went to a naturopath, told her all my symptoms and she gave me Kaprex A.I., made by Metagenics.  You cannot buy this off the shelf--have to get it through a naturopath or possibly a chiropractor.  This made all the difference in the world for me in terms of pain--I could move again!  I also take glucosamine for my joints.  For the hot flashes I notice if I consume a lot of caffeine they are much more noticeable. Hope this helps!
Posts.Title: Aromasin and Arimidex

Posts.Content: Thanks for asking this question.  It's something I've wondered about too.  As for me I think part of it was stress and grief (we moved and I did not want to, my baby went off to college, my mom died and my oldest was seriously depressed), part was poor diet and no exercise, and part was always putting everyone else first.  I took care of everyone but myself.  Now I've changed my diet (lost 60 lbs), am in an exercise class but need to do more, and I'm seeing a psychotherapist to deal with the anger and grief and learn how to set limits and understand that it's OK to put myself at the top of the list.

The best source to find out if this is true is your pharmacist.  They know which medicines are not supposed to be taken together.  You should tell them what you are currently taking and ask about the Cymbalta and Zoloft.
