Posts.Title: Aromasin and Arimidex

Posts.Content: On 8/7/2008 Cookiemouse wrote: Hi,  I have used this board before for my mom who had colon cancer.  I actually have a question about myself.  I am 36 yrs old and have 2 small kids...my mom passed in March of this year...I accidentally became pregnant and had to have an abortion in May of this year.  In the past few months, I have had weird breast sensations, hard, tenderness, some discharge when squeezed (only one occasion) and it looked like milk...it kind of comes and goes.   I have just been very aware of it.  I had a mammogram done at 35 (clear, thank god)...have had an irregularity in my menstrual cycle (but I have never been regular before).   Recently had a breast exam by my gyno and he did not say anything was wrong.  My question is:  should I investigate further or do you think it has to do with the pregnancy and menstrual cycle.  And if I should investigate, what should I look at?  Since my gyno was not concerned.  Thanks for all your help.  A suggestion:  If you haven't already, obtain a copy of your records, including mammo report.  Then get a second opinion from another gyno, making sure that dr. has your films to look at and a complete medical history, incl. family history of cancer.  Ask all your questions and keep asking until you receive an answer in plain English (as opposed to "med-speak").  Before you go, start keeping a record of when the sensations occur and when you get your period. Actually it would also be good to write down all your questions ahead of time---that way you won't forget any.  The more info you can give to the dr. about what you're experiencing, the better able the dr. will be to respond.  Yes, it could all be connected to the pregnancy, meaning it's hormonal, but it'd be nice to hear it confirmed, right?  Good luck and God bless.
Posts.Title: need some advice

Posts.Content: On 9/10/2008 courtney1 wrote: I had a lumpectomy last Jan. and just finished chemo, radiation etc. I visited with a plastic surgeon today about reconstruction. I had infection and have a indentation in the side of my left breast along with the nipple pulled to the side. Has anyone ever had flap surgery (from the back muscle), and what were your results. How did the recovery go? Is there a wait period after radiation? Also I am having pain under my arm and along the bra line under the breat, has anyone ever had that before? Thanks in advance for you help. You might want to also look into DIEP and related microsurgeries.  Check out www.diepflap.com.  This type of surgery does not involve taking a muscle, just uses your own body tissue.  Remember that radiation keeps on affecting your body for quite a while.  If I were you I'd wait 6-12 months before another surgery to give yourself a chance to recupe.  Your body's just been through an awful lot of stress. IF you have some swelling where you're having pain you should be checked for lymphedema.  Swelling after radiation is normal but having radiation also increases your chances of lymphedema (as does the surgery).  The pain could also be caused by the muscles and fascia tightening up from radiation so be sure to stretch EVERY day at least once (I usually do it after my shower & before bed).  You will need to do this for the rest of your life to stay limber.  The radiation (I'm told by my lymphedema therapist) will keep on affecting you for up to 2-3 years.  There is now laser therapy connected to lymphedema treatment that also helps with a lot of the pains associated w/treatment.  I've had laser treatment to my mastectomy scar in addition to my lymphedema and it does help.  I also see a massage therapist every week and that has helped tremendously with the pain and restricted movement. Hope this helps.  Congratulations, you've made it through the hardest part! Give yourself time to rejuvenate---every day you will feel a little better and you'll be amazed what a difference a year, and then another will make when you look back.
Posts.Title: LD flap surgery

Posts.Content: Linda Louise, I am so sorry to hear how painful your side effects are.  Any chance you could see an accupuncturist or chiropractor?  What does the doc say about the effects of all those pain meds on your system? I am on Arimidex and was told I'd be on it for 5 years.  Somehow that's the magic number. You're in my prayers.
Posts.Title: Aromitase Inhibitors

Posts.Content: On 6/14/2007 Garagegirl wrote: Hi: I have discovered an unusual lump in one of my breasts. I check myself regularly because of family history and the fact that I have dense breasts and my doctor has told me to be on top of this. I have had several "scares" over the years but it always turns out to be nothing. The lump I have is not round. It's more long - about one inch - and possibly 1/4 to 1/2 inch wide. I have never had anything like this before. Has anyone else had this type of lump. And, I know this sounds weird, but it is more noticeable at night than first thing in the morning. Thanks in advance for any info/advice.   It's good you are so diligent in your self-exams.  You mention you have dense breasts and I wonder, given your mention of family history, if you have ultrasounds in addition to mammograms.  Mammograms do not pick up all cancers, particularly in dense breasts!  I am proof of that.  I had invasive lobular carcinoma.  That kind of cancer grows along the lobules, in the shape of the lobule.  So before you freak yourself out, go see your doc and get it checked out.  If you haven't been having ultrasounds insist on it!  I wish you all the best.
Posts.Title: Unusual lump

Posts.Content: I agree you should look into all the different options of reconstruction---including micro-surgery called DIEP flap (I learned about this on these boards) which involves a tummy tuck but does not take muscle from a different area to use in constructing a breast.  Apparently recovery is shorter too.  If you need radiation you'll need to wait 6-12 months before doing reconstruction and that's OK, consider it recuperation time and time to get stronger before you undergo another operation.  Reconstruction is a very personal decision, in my opinion, and you are certainly not too old to have it!
Posts.Title: Five days since mastectomy

Posts.Content: I take Arimidex but also had the bad joint pain.  I went to a naturopath who took a very thorough medical history, had me bring in all my supplements and went through those and then gave me a supplement called Kaprex A.I. which is manufactured by Metagenics.  It has made a tremendous difference!  My hips no longer ache.  I also take 2000 units of D3/day (per my gynocologist) which we should all be taking---helps bones and inflammation.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: femara side effects

Posts.Content: Try accupuncture for the bone pain.  Worked for me when I took Neupogen shots during chemo and had horrible bone pain.  Am now taking a supplement called Kaprex by Metagenics for the arthritis-type pain that comes with Arimidex (I too felt like I was 80 when I stood up) and that has helped a lot.  My naturopathic physician recommended it.
Posts.Title: Bone Pain

Posts.Content: On 6/13/2007 Teacherjean wrote: I have 3A breast cancer and chose to have have mastectomy.  It has been 13 days since my first chemo treatment and I noticed today that my hair appears to be thinning a little.  Would someone share at what point their hair came out.  I go Thursday for Round 2 of chemo.  Also, I did pretty well after Round 1, only couple of rough days.  Is that what I can expect or will it get worse? So far everyone's told you about the hair on your head but no one's mentioned all the other places!  Don't be surprised to find you're just as upset to lose eyebrows, eyelashes and pubic hair.  I found that to be true.  Also the hair on my head went first, eyelashes and eyebrows came out the very last treatment, much to my dismay.  I have also found that my hair hasn't grown back as thick as it was and this includes eyebrows and eyelashes.  Now on my legs that's a good thing! As far as your physical reaction to treatment---everyone's different---depends on your overall health, other pre-existing conditions, which drugs you're on, how healthy you're able to eat, etc.  I was in excellent health when I was diagnosed (I was also 3A and had mastectomy & 24 nodes removed), had Neulasta or Neupogen shots after each treatment (those have their own side effects) plus did accupuncture, sometimes needed Procrit shots, was still a bit nauseous even with the anti-nausea drugs (be aware that some of them can constipate you---another problem to deal with!), food smelled and tasted weird so I ended up losing 20 lbs.(I had it to spare ; 0 ), and I was incredibly tired.  The fatigue and weakness was something that built up gradually so by the last treatment I was really REALLY tired and really glad to be done. I wish you all the best on your journey through this treatment.  Be kind to yourself, don't sweat the small stuff of life, learn as much as you can about your particular cancer and treatments and pepper your docs with questions!  Expect to have high and low spots--both emotionally and physically---and remember that you can get through them,.  Just don't think you've got to do it alone.  We're here, join a support group (very helpful!), say yes to help from family & friends.  I just passed my 1 yr. mark in April.  A year from now you'll be feeling much better--keep that as the light at the end of the tunnel.
Posts.Title: hair lose and chemo effects

Posts.Content: You have every right to have melt downs---you are going through major stress!!  Sucking it in will only result in headaches, ulcers, or crabbiness!  Don't put the additional expectation on yourselves that you have to be cheerful and upbeat all the time.  And don't let anybody else do that to you either!  Really now, who's cheerful all the time? Yes you may have friends who have a worse diagnosis---that does not negate what you have and what you're experiencing.  Sometimes having a professional, who's dealt with cancer patients, to talk to can be very very helpful.  They will understand the grief, guilt, rage, etc. that we ALL go through on this journey.  For others it's their support group that provides that listening sympathetic ear.  Decide what's best for you and be gentle to yourself---now more than ever. I wish you all the best.
Posts.Title: emotional support

Posts.Content: Since drugs are not helping much you might want to consider something like craniosacral massage therapy.  Find an Upledger trained therapist--they're the best.  They can help with chronic pain.  It is a gentle technique.
Posts.Title: post masectomy pain syndrome

Posts.Content: On 12/2/2007 Jeema6 wrote: Hi, I have been diagnosed with stage II breast cancer that spread to 1 lymph node (out of 4).  I am presently taking chemo (YUK) and I'm trying to keep the daily feeling of nausea at bay.  But my question is related to the estrogen part.  I am 50 yrs old and although I have had night sweats for several years, I am told that I am not even peri-menapausal yet!  This freaks me out because I am afraid of the estrogen still in my body.  Am I a candidate for partial hysterectomy?  I do not want to be on Tamoxifen for 5 years...I do not want hormone replacement.....HELP!!!!! I'm curious to know how it was determined that you aren't even perimenopausal, esp. since you've had night sweats.  I was diagnosed at age 52--stage 3 w/ 16 of 24 positive nodes, still had periods, and was told that chemo would almost definitely stop my periods, which it did by the 3rd session.  Remember that the chemo is wiping out the cancer--that'll help you get through it.  The term "hormone therapy" really should be "anti-hormone therapy" since the goal is to stop your body's production of estrogen.  So you will either be on Tamoxifen or one of the aromatase inhibitors for 5 years.  Do your homework and read up on these.  Start with Susan Love's Breast Book (latest edition)---she has lots of helpful info.  Also pepper your oncologist with these questions and see what she has to say.  Unless you are positive for BRCA I doubt your dr. would recommend a hysterectomy---why ask for more surgery if you really don't need it?  Good luck on your journey.  You can make it through the intense treatment, give yourself LOTS of time to heal (more than you think you'll need) and you'll be amazed at how much better you'll feel a year from now.
Posts.Title: Stopping the Estrogen

Posts.Content: On 10/30/2008 angel bear wrote: I just had my 2nd masectomy two weeks ago. Now it's in 11 of my 13 lymph nodes. Has anyone had it go into lymph nodes? Did they do chemo or radiation after? Hi Angel Bear, I had a single mastectomy and 16 of 24 lymph nodes tested positive.  I had both chemo & radiation.  I was also stage 3A which means larger than 5 cm tumor & large # of lymph nodes involved but no cancer into the chest wall.  I did the every 3 wk chemo with Adriamycin, Cytoxin & Taxotere for 18 wks, then about 35 sessions of radiation.  That was 2 1/2 yrs. ago.  I continue to do therapies to improve my quality of life and recover from the side effects of those initial treatments and I'm doing great.  Hang in there!  We're rootin' for ya!
Posts.Title: 2nd masectomy, 2weeks ago

Posts.Content: Google Herceptin to find out side effects.  If they want her to take that it means the cancer is HER2+ and Herceptin is very good at fighting that.  You need to find out the name of the pill and also what kind of chemo regimen so you can find out the side effects of those.  What do the drs. say about treatment in regards to her pre-existing conditions?  All good questions to ask before deciding what to do.
Posts.Title: Need help quickly

Posts.Content: On 8/25/2007 imafighter wrote: About two months ago I found this site after having an abnormal pap. Later it turned out to be mild dysplaisa, which is alittle scary. I am thankful thought it is not worse. In April of this year I had a breast reduction. Everything went wonderful and I healed up pretty quickly.  About a month ago I felt a lump in my breast.  I went to see my doc about it and he said he thought it maybe a cyst but he wanted me to have an ultrasound to be sure. So I went for the ultrasound and then they said we need to mamm. So I did that. They told me it looked like fat scl. or scar tissue but nothing to be worried about. They said that I should go see my doc in month and have him check it out again and then another ultrasound in about 6 months. I said ok and was like ok, nothing to worry about see your fine. Then boom! I get a letter in the mail saying that i had some abnormalites and need a bio. I was so mad. Why did they say everything was ok if it wasnt. I am glad everything is being taken care of but it is just so stressful. I am so confused and have no idea what is going on any advise would be helpful thanks. Hi "Ima" (love the name!) Better they wrote you back (although a phone call would have been nice, don'tcha think??) right away.  Now you go in, get biopsied, and find out if this is something to be concerned about or not.  I would assume they must have had another radiologist look at your films and that's when the abnormality was spotted.  Maybe the abnormality is something to do with your breast reduction, so try to be as calm as you are able.  Have someone go with you for support when you go in for the biopsy.  And don't be afraid to ask LOTS of questions about what they think they saw. Good luck, hope everything turns out benign!
Posts.Title: Confused

Posts.Content: On 8/17/2007 Cavman wrote: Yes,she is Her2 Positive. She is a little frail so the doctors recommend Herceptin, no chemo and they say they will moniter her heart because of previous strokes (2) and previous irregular heartbeat. The pill proposed is a Hormonal Therapy medication. She says with her age (74) and condition she doesn`t want any more medication to make her feel more tired. She is kind of giving up and I am so depressed about it. I recently fought a stage 4 tonsil/lymphnode cancer and I want her to fight as I did. Ron (her son) Ah, this must be so hard for you, especially after fighting cancer yourself. I would say the Herceptin is the most important.  The hormonal therapy drugs are a class called aromatase inhibitors--there are 3 of them--Arimidex, Aromisin and Femara.  They can have some severe side effects---it seems to depend on the person.  Check out Breast Cancer Action's website for a study done on the side effects as reported by women taking them.  The study is easy to read as it's broken down by each drug, age of the women, and side effects.  Some ages report higher percentages of certain side effects than others.  The website is bca.org. Your Mom's doctors should have given her/you a print-out indicating the survival rates for someone her age and health if she does or does not do the various therapies.  Make sure they explain it in plain English and listen carefully.  They are careful to make the distinction between over-all survival and recurrence.  There is an 88 yr. old lady in my support group who has decided not to take Arimidex (she's now survived both ovarian and breast cancer) because the graphs show she's likely to die of something else before she'd die of cancer.  She talked to her doctors over many weeks and kept asking questions before she finally came to that choice.  Ultimately that's what it comes down to---the patient's choice.  The thing is to make sure the patient is fully informed and actually hearing/processing the information.  If you feel she is giving up already consider talking to her oncologist about antidepressants and/or some sessions with a therapist.  Many people still hear the word "cancer" and believe it's a death sentence when that isn't necessarily so.  It's not unusual to be depressed with what she's facing.  But depression can also keep her from fully hearing/understanding her options.  Be as encouraging as you can with her.  I'm sure you must be an inspiration having survived stage 4. Please consider taking her to a nutritionist/dietician who specializes in cancer patients (this will not likely be covered by insurance).  Nutrition and supplements are going to be very important for her as will even the smallest amount of exercise (a walk around the block).  That all makes tolerating treatment easier.  If she's able to attend a support group that will also help.  My group has a wide variety of ages---30's to 90+ and we all learn so much from each other. If you haven't subscribed, do look up Cure online (I think it's www.cure.com ).  That's the magazine associated with the Lance Armstrong Foundation and it's free to cancer patients.  New subscribers also get a reference booklet.  Go to their archives and look at the Survivor's Issue of Summer 2006 (if they still have them available order one!), which is chock-full of lots of helpful info.  I read this during my chemo last year and it was inspiring and brought me hope. I wish you and your Mom the best.  Keep up your spirits, do nice little things for yourselves, rent funny movies, and don't give up because, as you discovered with your cancer, a bad prognosis doesn't always mean the cancer can't be beat or managed.
Posts.Title: Need help quickly

Posts.Content: On 10/12/2007 pandies wrote: Hello.. new here.. i have been taking tomoxifen for almost five years.. am now post menopausal so my doc put me on Arimidex.. ALL my life my blood pressure was a bit low.. now it is high.. so went off Arimidex.. my question to all of you is ... has anyone experienced high blood pressure from this medication.. along with rapid heart beat and palpitations? Now my fam doctor wants to put me on Topral ... have read the sides of this med and am not risking taking it.. because I believe my high blood pressure and palpitations are from Arimidex.. I have been off my arimidex since September 28... any help or answers is appreciated.. Patricia  High blood pressure is one of the side effects of Arimidex that I've read about.  Don't know about the palpitations but if nothing else changed for you except starting Arimidex then it seems logical that that is what caused the problems.  What did your oncologist suggest concerning the high blood pressure and palpitations?
Posts.Title: arimidex side effects

Posts.Content: On 10/3/2007 Barb B wrote: I have been on Armidex for four years and have decided that I am going to quit taking this medication. I called AstraZeneca's Cancer Support Network (              1-8...       ) to see if they had any statistics on how long the side effects last after discontinuing and they have not done any clinical studies on this. The only information they had for me is that is takes up to ten days for the medication to leave your system. I suggested that maybe a clinical study on this part of discontinuing the medication would be a smart thing to do. They acted as if I was the only person to ever ask this question. Maybe if more of us called, they world do a study that would answer a lot of the unanswered questions we all seem to have. Although I wholeheartedly agree with your idea of a study on how long Arimidex's side effects last after discontinuing use, I seriously doubt AstraZeneca would ever fund such a study.  What monetary gain would there be in it for them?  It certainly wouldn't sell more pills (unless maybe they went head-to-head against the other 2 aromatase inhibitors and came out with better results, i.e., less long-lasting side effects.)
Posts.Title: Side effects of Armidex

Posts.Content: With all the cancer in your family you might want to be screened more carefully.  I assume you've told your doctor your family history.  You could also do genetic testing.  Just because others in the family have had cancer does not automatically mean you will.  If I were you I would certainly pay very very careful attention to my diet and eat very cleanly, which means lots of fruits, veggies and nuts/seeds (organic if you can) with little to no meats and animal products (and no red meat) and no sugar or artificial/manmade ingredients. I would also not eat anything fried.  Another crucial component to staying healthy is exercise.  Look up info on alkaline diets--cancer cannot live in an alkaline environment.
Posts.Title: scaring having breast cancer

Posts.Content: On 10/25/2007 tiredone wrote: Do any of you know the symptoms of brain mets? I think I have had a couple of seizures in my sleep and have lost 12 pounds in less than 1 yr. I also have weakness in arms and legs, but that seems to come and go, so I don't see how it could be mets. I was dx with stage 2b BC Jan. 2003. ER+ and three nodes +. Thanks. MK      Hi MK, If I were you I would definitely be seeing my dr. and telling about all these symptoms.  I would also be asking for a brain MRI---better to find brain mets early when it is easier to treat and you have not lost quality of life.  And if the MRI is normal then you have piece of mind. Do some research on symptoms before you have your appt., then you're prepared with info and questions so you don't get the brush-off.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: symptoms of brain mets?

Posts.Content: Hi I'm a survivor who developed osteoporosis 2 1/2 years after treatment (I take Arimidex).  My naturopath put me on strontium (pills) and it has helped stabilize the bone loss.  Strontium helps the bones so it makes sense that your Mom's doctor wants to give it to her.  Have you asked the dr. about side effects and/or researched it online?  Good places to start.  Blessings to you both.
Posts.Title: Mets to the bone to receive Strontium

Posts.Content: Hi Joan, I'm surprised no one's answered you. Lots of women write on this board about the weight gain with the aromatase inhibitors--whether it's Arimidex, Aromasin or Femara. I'm on Arimidex (8 months) and have gained 9 lbs. I find if I eat a very low fat mostly vegetarian diet then I can lose. I've tried to eliminate sugar, eat starches early in the day (and not a lot) and don't drink alcohol except for special occasions. For those thinking oh yuck, how boring that still leaves PLENTY of interesting healthy foods. I'm not a saint, I do love chocolate and indulged over Halloween (and gained and had to re-lose). I have 2 motivators: lymphedema (which I have) is more manageable if you are at a normal weight and survivor statistics say those who are at a normal BMI survive the longest. I try to follow Dr. Joel Fuhrman's Eat To Live book and advice--that's been helpful and inspiring. I still have to put the exercise part in place. There's lots to do towards keeping healthy, isn't there?
Posts.Title: Metabolism impacted by Aromasin

Posts.Content: On 7/31/2008 brawleymom wrote: I am almost a year out from my mastectomy but am still doing reconstruction. I have a gel implant and last week had a dog ear removed. Nipple comes next. Throughout my entire cancer journey, my rib cage has been tender, but more so lately.  Is this possible still a year later?  My bra hurts it, and every once in awhile I will get those throbbing pain under the rib cage but most of the time it just aches. It even looks like it sticks out more on that side. Of course I am terrified of bone mets or even liver mets and will ask my onco when I go next month, but my husband keeps reminding me that this has bothered me the whole time--I just think it is worse now.  Some people have said rib cage pain is common--just wondering if it would continue even a year later?  Ache is not bad enough to take anything...maybe an Ibuprofen or something. Also, it does not seem to hurt as much when i get up. Any advice to help my sanity would be great. By the way, I did not have chemo or radiation, nor do i take any pills. Cancer was a wierd one, with a 6 cm tumor. Surgeon told me she was very aggressive in getting all the tissue out. your help is appreciated!   Molly    It very well may have to do with the surgery.  Your insides really get yanked around while they're trying to get all the cancer out.  I have been seeing a cranio-sacral massage therapist, who also does myofascial release and visceral manipulation, and he has helped with my rib/chest pain a lot, not to mention my range of motion through the shoulder and neck.  Another thought is to try accupuncture for the pain. Hope this helps!
Posts.Title: Ribcage pain a year later?

Posts.Content: On 5/5/2007 Waquin wrote: I had a bilateral (double) mastectomy April 11, 2007. I had no pain whatsoever for the first nine days. On the ninth day, the surgeon removed my drain tubes. Then the fluid started building up in my chest wall around my incisions. And then, the pain started! I went and had the fluid aspirated from my chest. The pain has been relentless since then. I have folds of skin below my incisions, which are swollen and hard, and very painful!  This swelling continues over under my armpits. I tried the Darvocet that the surgeon gave me, but it made me sick, very nauseous and impaired my respiratory system ( I could hardly breathe). Does anyone have any suggestions? The pain is becoming unbearable. I don't sleep at night and I try to sleep during the day, without much success.             Hi Waquin, You shouldn't have to suffer constant pain.  Please go back to your surgeon (be insistent with the front desk that you need to see the doctor NOW!) and very carefully articulate where it hurts, what's different from the 1st nine days, and how the pain is now constant.  There has to be something else they can give you for pain that you can tolerate.  It may be you need to have the fluid aspirated again but if not then ask your doctor if the swelling could be lymphedema as opposed to edema.  There is a special massage and bandaging that they can do to reduce swelling with lymphedema and the sooner you catch it the better. Hope this helps.
Posts.Title: Post bilateral mastectomy pain

Posts.Content: On 4/10/2008 CelerySisters wrote: Hi, I am writing because yesterday my 25 y.o. sister was told by her oncologist to "prepare for a cancer diagnosis." We are many states away from one another and all I want to do is fly out to be with her right now but I have a husband in law school and three children at home, so I have to wait another week before I can get out there. She is so afraid and has so many questions, but she was so overwhelmed by this news that she didn't ask any questions while she was in the office and isn't scheduled to go back until Monday. She had a needle biospy done yesterday. I'm not sure of all the logistics of this (I have zero knowledge of cancer, we have no family members who have been touched by the disease thus far) so forgive my ignorance. In front of her, they put the specimen in some kind of solution and told her that if it floated, it meant that it was "fatty deposits/cysts." Well it sunk.  My question is how likely is it that it can still be a cyst? The oncologist did not give her a good vibe when he said, "Prepare for a cancer diagnosis." Words of knowledge or advice from anyone with experience with this would be greatly appreciated. My sister is just so petrified. She has a 10 month old baby girl. Thank you for listening. Dear CelerySis, Ah she's so young!  I pray the diagnosis isn't cancer but the oncologist's words seem to indicate otherwise.  So I will give some advice.  If the diagnosis is cancer, then first, make sure your sister gets a second opinion and has a different lab look at the slides of her biopsy.  Some women get more than 2 opinions.  She should ALWAYS have someone go to appts with her.  Two heads remember more than one and the other person should be an advocate for her if she's not feeling up to questioning the drs. Interview at least 2 oncologists and get their recommendatins for treatment.  Go with the one she feels most comfortable with and whose treatment recommendations she agrees with.  Vitally important to remember that she gets to choose her treatment.  If it's possible where she is, going to a cancer center is a good idea--having a team of drs. (oncologist, radiation oncologist, gynocologist, dietician, surgeons) working together helps.  If not, it's up to her to coordinate information btw drs.  Don't assume they talk to each other!!!!  VERY IMPORTANT:  Have her get copies of every dr and lab report, bills, insurance explanation of benefits, etc.  Keep them organized in a 3-ring binder.  I did this and it's extremely helpful. Get Dr. Susan Love's The Breast Book (most current edition) which is a wealth of information about types of cancer, treatments, reconstruction (except it's missing the latest reconstruction--microsurgery with DIEP flap).  If your sister's diagnosis is inflammatory BC, she will want to move quickly with treatment.  If not, then she has a bit more time to decide how she wants to proceed.  Dr. Love's book doesn't really address complementary treatment so do some research on that.  Diet is important--she should be eating an alkaline diet (again research on Web).  Although insurance probably doesn't cover it, a visit with a dietician familiar with cancer patients is incredibly helpful (remember drs. typically get about 1 course in nutrition in med school so a nutritionist is much more knowledgable). She will need someone to organize a group of family, friends, neighbors, etc. to help her during treatment.  They can do laundry, dishes, grocery shopping, baby sitting, bring meals, whatever.  Your sister will need to focus on herself (something very hard for a young mother to do but very very necessary!!) and put her energy into getting well. I believe that cancer affects not just the body, but also involves the mind and spirit.  Certainly there are studies out there that confirm there is a mind/body connection.  An important book for me was Jean Shinoda-Bolen's Close to the Bone, Life threatening illness and the search for meaning.  I read the updated 10th anniversary edition and found it so helpful even 2 years after my diagnosis. As a sister you could also set up a CaringBridge website (free) for her so her friends & far-flung family can keep in touch.  My husband did that for me and I wrote on the website (it became like a journal) so everyone would know what was going on. Reading the encouraging messages everyone send me was very uplifting.  I printed out the messages and took them to the hospital with me (my "support group".)  A support group for young breast cancer patients would be very helpful for her if that's available in her community.  She will also find support on this website.  There are also several magazines I'd recommend: MAMM, Cure and Heal.  MAMM is specifically about breast & gynecological cancers, Cure covers all cancers and Heal is for those past initial treatment.   If I can help with any more info please feel free to send me a private reply and I will get back to you quickly.  My prayers and best wishes are with you both.
Posts.Title: 25 y.o. sister told to "prepare for cancer diagnosis."

Posts.Content: On 6/25/2007 Hollyhobby wrote: Thank you very much for the information, I now have alot more questions for my Doctor's. I will be looking into Cure also, didn't know that was available. Thanks so much! : ) Hollyhobby P.S.  Is it normal to feel like your going to have a complete heart attack at any moment when you find out that you have breast cancer?   Hi Holly, Absolutely normal to feel like you're going to have a heart attack, that's it's all surreal and tomorrow you'll wake up from the bad dream, etc., etc.  You will grieve, may feel very angry or resentful or be in denial, walk around in a fog, become hyper-aware of any and all cancer causing things from sun to foods, discover you can cry at the drop of a hat, and any number of other feelings.  It's all normal.  It's also extraordinarily helpful to join a support group and talk to others who've gone through it or are going through it.  It's also helpful to talk to a therapist or social worker---there are cancer-oriented ones out there.  If you feel like that's too much to heap on your plate at this time then wait a while until you're ready.  It's never too late to join a group or go to therapy.  I waited until I was finished with treatments but wish I'd had the energy to go to a group sooner.  It's been very inspirational.  Plus these women "get it" like no one else can.  We are all part of a sorority that we never wanted to join but here we are and everyone is incredibly supportive of each other. Another thing that helped me was my husband set up a CaringBridge website about me so friends from all over could keep in touch.  We printed out their messages and I took my "support group" with me to the hospital!  Was very comforting to read.  I regularly update my "journal" on the website to let folks know how I'm doing.  CaringBridge is free but your friends and family will have to be told a password in order to access your website, if you should set one up. One last recommendation:  There's a magazine called Mamm, which focuses on women and breast & gynecologic cancers.  They are also online at www.mamm.com and you can read some of the articles.  They charge for a subscription but it's not much (sorry can't remember right now!)  I just received the May/June 07 issue--good article on radiotherapy, choosing a doctor and an interview w/Dr. Susan Love (author of Dr. Susan Love's Breast Book). Blessings to you Holly.  Keep in touch.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy

Posts.Content: On 9/21/2007 Leemg wrote: The radiation won't affect your bone density.  As I said though Femara, one of the adjunct oral cancer drugs may, so if your medical oncologist chooses this category of meds after radiation then I would start taking calcium supplements about 1200 to 1500 mg and Vit. D about 400 to 600 but there are other drugs used that do not adversely affect the bone such as Tamoxifen or the new drug Avista.  If you don't already I would take a good multivitamin with mineral supplement, eat a good diet and your body will tell you when you need to rest which is important because the body needs energy to effectively use the radiation.  For skin redness etc. I started using Biafine radiation cream at the onset of my radiation therapy.  This is a prescription cream which worked wonders.  Don't be afraid to address any of these questions with your medical oncologist as well.  I agree with Lee about the supplements, though check with your radiation oncologist about taking anything during radiation. Something I did (not covered by my insurance but well worth $100) was see a nutritionist who specialized in cancer patients---she had lots of helpful suggestions, including which supplements to take.  After active treatment ended and I started Arimidex, my gynecologist upped my vitamin D dose to 2000 IU/day.  Make sure to get a vitamin D3 level test---mine was at the low end of normal (in the 20's) and she wanted me in the upper end (now it's in the 40's).  They are finding that D3 is a very important vitamin, not only for bone health but also possibly for inflammation.
Posts.Title: post menopausal 66 yr

Posts.Content: Dear Sam, So sorry to hear your Mom has breast cancer. I had stage 3, with 24 nodes removed and 16 involved. I just passed my 1 yr. since the end of chemo annniversary. Hang in there, you and your Mom will make it through this. There are drugs to help get her through chemo and the nausea & vomiting, however Taxotere is not one of them. Taxotere is one of the drugs used to fight cancer (I had this during my cancer treatment). You can search on the Web to find out what the side effects are of the drugs your mother is on. Remember she isn't likely to have every side effect. If she has had lots of vomiting her doctor should be informed and asked for something to stop it--she shouldn't have to just tough it out and the dr. won't want her to get dehydrated. Make her tea with a little ginger or mint in it and give it to her when it's tepid--not hot. Plain crackers or bread (no butter or anything greasy) may help also. Her sense of taste and smell may change which will make eating difficult but protein is especially important during treatment. Save her favorite foods for when she's done with chemo. Make her plain, small, frequent meals---not a lot of salt or seasonings. She may find something plain like applesauce will agree with her. As the treatments progress she will find she has additional side effects and will feel very very tired. Resting is important! One other thing I would advise you to watch for and that is swelling of her arm and/or hand. The chemo can cause swelling but swelling can also be an indication of lymphedema which she is at risk for since so many lymph nodes were removed. If her rings or clothes feel tight she should see a therapist trained in manual lymphatic drainage for an evaluation. I know, one more thing to deal with, but VERY important to deal with early rather than later. Please look at www.lymphnet.org as one place to learn about it. Blessings.
Posts.Title: Advice on side effects

Posts.Content: On 7/20/2008 baseballmaven wrote: Hi,   I had a lumpectomy and Sentinel Node biopsy in April, and felt like my breast and under arm had healed... I just finished chemotherapy and am starting radiation.  About a week ago I started having pain under my arm, on my side, and in my breast (which feels swollen, like just before one's period--but I'm post menopause)--it started soon after the simulation for the radiation, so I assumed it was due to the long period of time I had to lie with my arm in an uncomfortable position, but it isn't going away.   I called my surgeon who agreed that was probably the issue, as it wouldn't be post-surgical pain at this point.... but as I say, it's been over a week since the simulation... and it's not getting any better...  I don't know who to ask about this--the medical oncologist, the radiation oncologist or??? Or, am I just being dumb and it will go away on its own?  Any ideas?   Thanks so much. No, you are certainly NOT being dumb!  I would ask BOTH the oncos your question.  I would also HIGHLY recommend you get a referral to a lymphedema therapist to be checked for lymphedema.  Chemo can make you swell and radiation definitely makes you swell but if you have lyphedema and don't treat while you wait to see IF the swelling goes down after treatment is over, you will waste precious time and the lyphedema just gets worse.  Continue (or start) to get some exercise and stretch your affected arm up a wall at least 2X/day.  The radiation will tighten up all the muscles and you must stretch if you want to retain mobility.  Exercise is a huge help in controlling lymphedema (and also helps with the fatigue that sometimes comes with radiation treatment!) Hope this helps!  Blessings to you for your complete healing.
Posts.Title: Pain 3 months post surgery, post chemo, pre radiation

Posts.Content: On 7/20/2009 Kygrandma wrote: I was diagnosed last year with breast cancer and underwent radiation. I was then placed on Arimidex. I encountered numerous problems with stiffness of joints, agressive arthritis, and tons of muscular pain. Recently(thru a change of doctors) I was placed on Aromasin.  I am beginning to have more joint stiffness but am still trying this med.  There is a very noticable difference in my hair.  It is really thinning out.  Anyone with any suggestions?  Or has this impacted any one else???  I sure don't want to feel like LoneRanger. I'm on Arimidex (2+ yrs) and right after I was placed on it my hair started falling out and became much much thinner, particularly at the back of the crown and the front of the head. My solution to the hair problem was a human hair wig that clips to my hair.  No more bad hair days and thicker bangs than I'd ever had!  What I'd love to know from those who had this same problem is:  does the hair come in better once they quit the aromatase inhibitors?
Posts.Title: Hair Thinning Problems

Posts.Content: Also want to refer you to the message on this board titled "Waiting Period before action".  The responses from Akbet are terrific and can help your sister tremendously.  I would only add that she should take 2-3 Tablespoons of organic ground Flaxseed every day.
Posts.Title: 25 y.o. sister told to "prepare for cancer diagnosis."

Posts.Content: Not to scare you but the phrase "clear margins" is important and it is not unusual for the margins not to be clear the first time, which means the surgeon would have to go back and remove more tissue in order to get clear margins. A sentinel node dissection reduces the chance of lymphedema but does not guarantee that you won't get it.  Any time the lymph system is disrupted, either by surgery, radiation, injury or whatever, there is a chance of lymphedema occurring.  Check out the National Lymphedema Network for tips on how to avoid it and remember lymphedema can occur many many years later so make those tips a part of your regular routine. Good luck on your treatment.  Make sure you've got a good support system, be gentle to yourself, and remember you will be recovering for a year after your treatment ends.  Please do not expect to be back to normal right after your last session.  Mentally and physically you will have been through a lot---allow yourself time to heal and deal with everything. I highly recommend the magazine CURE as a source of inspiration and information.  You can sign up for it online---it is free to cancer patients.  You can also look at back issues online---check out their 2006 special Survivors issue----incredibly helpful.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy

Posts.Content: I would hope you're getting or have gotten a 2nd and/or 3rd opinion which concurrs with your surgeon.  Express your doubts/fears about no surgery and expect to get an understandable answer!  Have someone with you to take notes and listen carefully.  Make sure everyone is on the same page concerning meanings and terminology (I've found that my interpretation of a phrase is different from my drs.)  Hope this helps.
Posts.Title: Stage iv - no Surgery

Posts.Content: It certainly could be lymphedema!  Lymph is a protein-rich fluid so I wonder if there might be a test to determine what the fluid is that's draining.  You need to pester your doctor for answers to your questions--they don't always think of lymphedema as a possible problem.  He may just think it's edema from the surgeries.  Edema can go away but lymphedema is for life and needs to be managed.  Lymphedema makes you more susceptible to infection in the affected area.  Early treatment is very important both to avoid infection and reduce the swelling.  Check out lymphnet.org for good info.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: post-surgery breast limphedema?

Posts.Content: Hi Anni, Please go to Dr Susan Love's website to read about breast cancer and things to ask drs. I just saw the surgeon for a check-up this week (I'm 2 1/2 yrs. post-mastectomy) and asked about micro-calcifications.  She explained everyone has some calcifications and they look for oddly shaped, small ones and also patterns of groups.  Those are the suspicious ones. Sounds like you are getting everything in order, which is great.   Keep listening to your gut about what you need and keep asking questions.  If you can, bring someone with you (a friend?) to help take notes and write down the dr's answers.  It's hard to remember everything when you're scared. Blessings to you.
Posts.Title: something of concern in recent mamo and ultrasound I'm scared...

Posts.Content: On 10/15/2007 MCatherine wrote: Bon jour! Someone told me the if you have breast cancer, your breast do not hurt.  I was told that having a few tender areas in not a big deal. We need each other.  I am not sure who to ask because I have had enough mamograms to find something by now.  I do not take any hormones.... One question:  Is breast cance a silent pain, or can your breast feel sore to the touch in certain areas? Thanking you in advance, MaryCatherine   Breast cancer is NOT always silent.  I woke up with a sore breast and an inverted nipple.  I was diagnosed with Stage 3A invasive lobular carcinoma last year.  I had 16 positive lymph nodes.  I also had regular mammmos but dense breasts (no one ever told me that mammos aren't very good at seeing cancer in dense breasts).  I am a survivor of 1 1/2 yrs and intend to live to a ripe old age (I'm 54).  A friend of mine also had pain and ended up with a bilateral mastectomy in her early 40's.  My advice, if you have dense breasts (and your mammo report would mention that), is to have an ultrasound done.  Then you can have piece of mind.  Your pain could be cysts, which your dr. should be able to tell you and should also have some recommendations on dealing with them.  There may be dietary suggestions that would help.  Please make an appointment with your gynecologist soon!
Posts.Title: I am 58. My breast hurt all the time....

Posts.Content: On 7/2/2007 Jean1 wrote: Hi My mom who was diag. in dec with dcis .Had a full mysectomy and 6 nodes all neg is just finishing 4 sessions of chemo .She is 72 she wants to know how do they determine if she is "cancer free"or in remission .she she have any additional tests and what should she "watch" for ?She is also very weak and tired after chemo any ideas on how to help boost her energy level..she would love to start traveling but is way to tired .She wants to have peace of mind that her cancer is gone .how do you kow?She sits home most of the time ..and I really would like her to start enjoyinhg herself so is fearful thast the cancer is not gone and seems depressed and isolates herself..any help or imfo would be great god bless ! tara Hi Tara, If your Mom has just finished chemo please be aware that it takes a year to recover from treatment for cancer.  She has just gone through a LOT for a 72 yr. old and her body and spirit need recuperating time.  If there is any way you can have an appt. with a dietician (someone who specializes with cancer patients), I highly recommend it.  I saw one and got lots of great advice, including that extra protein (good quality, not high fat) is important.  Make sure they are testing her white and red blood counts.  Low counts can make you tired, esp. low red counts.  I needed red cell booster shots after my last chemo (they automatically gave me white cell booster shots----Neupogen).  I traveled 3 weeks after my last chemo---flew to visit girlfriends (nothing like girlfriend therapy!!).  Yes, I was tired but I paced myself and didn't overdo, however I am 20 yrs. younger than your Mom.  If the oncologist said that the chemo was "insurance", then I would take that to mean that as far as they were able to tell, they got all the cancer with the operation.  Yes, yes there's always the chance that some cells traveled elsewhere but your Mom needs to believe they got it all and that her job now is to get strong and healthy again so her body is able to fight off ANY illness.  Basically this is what I've told myself and I had invasive lobular carcinoma with 16 positive lymphnodes---stage 3A.  I've looked at the chemo & radiation I've gone through as "insurance" to make sure no other little cancer cells left over had any chance to grow.  I've also had a PET/CT scan (that scans from about your knees to your chin, I think) and a mammogram and breast MRI of the other breast which showed no signs of cancer so these are other tests to help give her piece of mind  I would also encourage you to ask your questions (write them all down before you see the dr. so you'll remember) of the oncologist, including the ones about what to be on the watch for in terms of recurrence.  I did--actually asked the surgeon, oncologist AND radiation oncologist---covered all my bases! Hang in there.  It's wonderful you are taking care of your Mom.  Make sure she's eating properly and getting quality sleep--both important components of healing.  You'll both see the gradual improvement in strength and energy as time progresses.  If she can take little walks or a gentle exercise class that will also help her energy and healing.  Best to you both.
Posts.Title: How do you Know When You Are In Remission?

Posts.Content: Make sure she gets a PET/CT fusion scan and make sure she does the preliminary diet instructions. I would say her drs. are just being thorough. I was stage 3 with 16 pos. nodes last year. Had a PET scan shortly after mastectomy, this year had another (for peace of mind) and this year I read on the Web how Johns Hopkins, I believe it was, has patients prepare for a PET scan, so I did it that way even though my local place did not give me such diet restrictions. Search for PET scan preparation and you'll find what I'm referring to.
Posts.Title: PET and Brain Scan

Posts.Content: I had stage 3 BC also in 2006.  Went through chemo & radiation, also ended up with lymphedema.  Started Arimidex 3/07 and aches and hair loss started a few months later.  My hips were particularly bad, could hardly stand up in the morning or after sitting for any length of time.  I went to a naturopathic dr., who put me on Kaprex AI and a couple of other supplements, including a magnesium drink for help with sleeping.  The Kaprex has worked wonders!  I don't have the aches anymore.  My gynocologist also started me on 2000 units/day of D3 around the same time I started the Kaprex (which also has D in it) so I'm thinking the D is helping the joints counteract the Arimidex. So I'd recommend finding a naturopathic doctor (they have more training than just a naturopath) who will take a very detailed history and then recommend the appropriate vitamins/supplements/ tinctures for you.  BTW mine is also helping with the lymphedema.
Posts.Title: Adjunct therapy

Posts.Content: On 10/22/2008 "tigger" wrote: had radical breast cancer surgery, last year the final reconstructive part of the surgery was 1 week before christmas last year. the question i have is why do i still feel alone and sometimes feel like a freak, for lack of better words. when will i start to feel normal and/or like my self again.still feel like crying but not as much as i had in the past few months. feel like i need to talk to someone that has went through the same thing. i'm really new at this and don'treally know if i'm doing the right thing ,but am willing to try and talk with someonethis way   Dear tigger, Your feelings are very normal.  You've been through a war and now that you've survived you finally have a chance to feel again rather than be in "fight" mode.   I'd like to suggest a support group and/or a talk therapist who works w/cancer survivors.  I started both after I finished surgery, chemo & radiation and it's helped a lot.  I'm still going 2 1/2 yrs. out from surgery.  It helps to talk to others who've been through what you've been through.  A good therapist can help you sort through the lonely feelings and grief (that's part of the tears) and help you get to a better place emotionally.  If you don't know where to look to find these folks ask your oncologist for a referral. Blessings to you and know that we've all been where you are.  You're not alone in your feelings.
Posts.Title: radical breast surgery

Posts.Content: Congratulations to you on your 8th anniversary!  Keep posting--we're always inspired by survivors!
Posts.Title: luck

Posts.Content: Ck out MD Anderson---see if they include complementary & alternative treatments in their regimen.  I do echo Tre's advice also.
Posts.Title: Doctors

Posts.Content: Hi Peter Pan, This was a technique for surgeons to use during breast cancer surgery so not applicable to you now.  However, as one who did develop lymphedema, I can recommend that you pay very close attention to your weight---being at your ideal weight is recommended and now that I'm about there my lymphedema isn't as bad as it was.  Pay close attention to how your rings, watch, sleeves of garments fit.  If they start to feel tighter and you know it isn't water retention, get yourself into a certified lymphedema therapist immediately, preferably LANA certified.  There is a LANA website to research therapists and also the National Lymphedema Network lists some.  There are different schools for lymphedema therapists but the gold standard training is Vodder, which is from Europe.  This is what both my therapists are trained in and it works!  If you don't find a listing of a therapist near you then call your local hospitals for referrals and question the therapists closely about their training.  I think the National Lymphedema Network website has a list of questions to ask a therapist.  If you catch lymphedema at Stage 1 I've read it can be reversed.  I did not have a good therapist at that stage plus was in denial so didn't go back immediately when it got worse.  Please learn from my mistakes and you'll save yourself a lot of grief.  I ended up going through Complete Decongestive Therapy twice---during radiation and once after radiation (radiation makes you swell)---with CDT your arm and hand are wrapped up in bandages 24/7 for 3 weeks except when you're receiving the Manual Lymphatic Drainage treatment---a specialized massage 3X/wk.  It was very very helpful for me and I'm glad I did it.  I was taught how to do the MLD, which I do every night.  I now wear a custom-made one piece glove/sleeve.  Most people wear a glove and separate sleeve but I had a lot of problems with my hand and the double pressure at the wrist was part of the problem.  This is not to say that everyone who gets lymphedema ends up wearing a sleeve and glove---some only need a sleeve, some need a sleeve and a gauntlet (fingerless glove).  Seeing someone who is an experienced fitter is also essential.  The first person I went to wasn't very good and I think she compounded my problems!  Also if your surgeon or dr. hasn't told you, depending on the extent of your surgery and lymph node removal, you should probably wear a sleeve and possibly a gauntlet when you fly or are up in the mountains. I also am part of a lymphedema support group, which is helpful and I attend a Lebed exercise class, which was developed for lymphedema patients.  I still see one of my therapists for MLD once a week---something I decided to do for myself since I feel she does a better job than I do (2 hands are better than 1, and it's relaxing!). Wow, now I've given you an earful!  I truly hope you do not get lymphedema.  There is ongoing research into the causes and possible different treatments.  They still don't know why some women who've had the same cancer, same treatments, get it and some don't and some will develop it 10-20 years later.  All you can do is pay attention to your body so you can be aware and catch it early.
Posts.Title: Informed patient

Posts.Content: On 9/30/2007 Bob Bon wrote: I have been cancer free for five  and a half months. I was on tamoxefen for two years and aromasin for three years.   I will continue with my aromasin until advised otherwise by my doctor. My problem is hair loss.  Does anyone out there  have  this problem?  Does anyone know ouwhat can help? I had sixr ounds of chemo in2002. My hair came back very thin.  It has gotten worst every year.  If anyone has any suggentions please  write.thanks bogey Hi Bogey, You are not alone.  I am also experiencing hair loss and I've been on Arimidex for 6 months.  It really stinks to finally be getting hair back only to have it start falling out again. I now know why The Donald has a comb-over!!  My oncologist confirmed it's the drug (although some women do experience hair thinning with menopause). I've done some Web research on female hair loss.  Read that some dermatologists recommend Vitamin B12, Biotin, and MSM.  I would see a dermatologist before taking anything, just to be sure it doesn't conflict with your current meds.  My onco also said there's a pill named Propecia for helping hair loss (I think that's right) but the side effect is lowered libido (no thanks!!)  There's also Rogaine.  One website I found was a guy who writes about trying just about everything and what worked for him.   Check out baldingtony.com and save yourself some research.  At least we'll know what not to try!  Also if hair replacement surgery has crossed your mind (it did mine!)--forget it, not really applicable for women due to the patterns of hair loss.  Plus some of those operations are really just a scam cause they do not work the way they're advertised---you just end up looking worse. Ah well, there's always wigs, eh?
Posts.Title: hair loss

Posts.Content: At your mother's age you need to consider quality of life issues versus medicines which may prevent breast cancer recurrence.  Please check carefully the side effects for aromatase inhibitors---go to Breast Cancer Action's website (bca.org) and look at the self-reported list of side effects.  They are arranged by age groups and the particular AI so it's very easy to read.  If she's just gotten relief from back pain and was having it with Arimidex, Aromasin may not be any different.  Ultimately it's up to her how much pain she wants to put up with but a good talk with the dr. about controlling side effects would be a good thing.  I wish you both the best on this journey.
Posts.Title: Switching from Arimidex to Aromasin

Posts.Content: On 10/23/2008 Talli4726 wrote: Does anyone have any suggestions for treating or managing the extreme pain due to chemo neuropathy in my feet.  I had stage 3 breast cancer, double mastectomy and chemo. I've tried Folic Acid and vitamin B to no avail. Thanks to all who respond!    If you haven't already, you should tell your onco you're in extreme pain. There are meds they can prescribe.  I've heard Eucerin Calming Creme can help too.  The vitamin B should be a B complex.  Check with a cancer nutritionist too.  Another gal I know went to the acupuncturist for help.  Make SURE you are wearing roomy shoes w/extra room in the toe box.  You may find you need a larger size than your usual size, also they should be flat or nearly flat so no extra pressure is put on your toes and the ball of your foot. Also check this website: http://www.cancersymptoms.org/peripheralneuropathy/preventiv Best of luck and blessings to you.
Posts.Title: Neuropathy in feet

Posts.Content: On 5/18/2007 Writeangel wrote: Great article about how important it is to be an informed patient. Only problem is that doctors don't want to hear from informed patients. If you've talked to another doctor or nurse, read something in a magazine or on the Internet, or spoken with a survivor, it doesn't matter. The truth of the matter is that YOUR doctor is going to tell you that a)  you can't trust what you've heard or b) it's true, but it doesn't apply to your case. I'd love to believe that that self educating I've done about breast cancer has helped me in some way. The truth is that all it does is tick off my doctors. Then maybe it's time to look for different docs.  You are entitled to be treated with respect and listened to.  I brought up an article about a neurosurgeon who's doing brain MRIs to find BC metasteses early (before symptoms show up and quality of life is diminished).  My oncologist agreed that a brain MRI was a good idea.  I also brought up the recommendation about breast MRIs for at-risk women and asked my surgeon if that applied to me.  She said it certainly did and now I have an appt. for a breast MRI, in addition to the mammogram on my remaining breast. I do believe that educating ourselves about this disease and treatments is very important.  Doctors know lots, but let's face it, they're busy busy busy----they may not see the latest news as quickly as a patient who spends a LOT of time researching.  When I bring in something I try to ask questions about it and I expect a considered answer (which I usually get).  Sometimes I return with more questions (chemobrain doesn't always allow me to remember everything or even remember to write it all down!)  I've given copies of things I've found to my surgeon (new technique to help avoid lymphedema---she hadn't heard of it yet) and to the PET scan people.  I give them in the spirit of "oh, have you heard about this yet?  I found it in this mag or this website"--then it's up to them to use the knowledge.  And why wouldn't the provider want new info to help them do their job better?? Just my two cents!
Posts.Title: Informed patient

Posts.Content: I should have also said that the National Lymphedema Network site does have a list of do's and don'ts to avoid lyphedema.  Lots are just common sense. I just went to a lecture by Dr. Stanley Rockson (Stanford University), who is a prominent lymphedema researcher.  He said moderate exercise is probably OK, provided you work into it really slowly.  You may find different advice elsewhere but this is the latest. Speaking of exercise, check out the book The Breast Cancer Survivor's Fitness Plan by Dr. Carolyn Kaelin, Francesca Coltrera, et al.  I found this at the book store.  Copyright is 2007 so it is full of current data, good info and written by survivors who just happen to be dr. and exercise experts.  The exercises start out very gently, with alterative ways to do them also given.  Exercises are also organized based on whether you had a mastectomy, lumpectomy, various reconstruction surgeries (except the microsurgeries) and advice for those with lymphedema.  An excellent book! I wish you the best in your healing and journey through this disease, Peter Pan.  I'm just a year ahead of you so if you have more questions feel free to write.
Posts.Title: Informed patient

Posts.Content: Get Dr. Susan Love's Breast Book, the latest edition.  It will tell you about the different breast cancers, different treatments, reconstructions (except micro-surgery), etc.  Very good informative book.
Posts.Title: Invasive Ductile Carcinoma

Posts.Content: I assume you're calling the lab?  Have you tried calling the surgeon's office?  If so and all you're getting is a run around there from the office, ask to have the surgeon call you personally.  Call every day until you get an answer.  What about enlisting the oncologist's help in getting those reports?  The hospital should have a patient advocate---get them going on it.  Become a pest that they'll respond to simply to get you to stop! ;>) To help put your mind at ease, I had a modified radical mastectomy with 24 nodes removed 4/11/06 and didn't start chemo until 5/26 (I flew to my best friend's wedding the week before chemo started).  The drs. OK'd that plan.  I feel it gave my body time to recuperate from the operation (and I took a bunch of supplements to prepare my body for chemo.)  I also had 8 weeks between the end of chemo & the start of radiation (that wasn't exactly planned, just happened that way, but I was also thankful to have a break to recuperate from the chemo) and then a 3 month break btw the end of radiation and starting Arimidex.  I just celebrated my 2 yr. anniversary. Hang in there and keep demanding answers.  I wish you all the best through this journey.
Posts.Title: Lost estrogen results?

Posts.Content: On 4/6/2007 Jewelsinalabama wrote: Still wondering if anyone in Alabama has had the DIEP procedure? You might try Googling "micro-surgeons Alabama" and see if there are any if you haven't been able to locate any under "plastic surgeon".  Those are the surgeons who would do the DIEP or SIEP procedures.  They are plastic surgeons with extra training.  This type of breast reconstruction is relatively new so make sure whomever you find has done it a number of times.  You don't want to be #1,2,3 or 5, for instance.  You also want to have it done at a facility that has specially trained nurses to care for you after the surgery.  They are trained to spot potential failure of the transplanted tissue even before machinery does. Good luck!  BTW, did you see the earlier message about DIEP from someone who had it done?  I thought she was from the south.... and her dr. is well known (has a good website too).  Sorry, chemobrain can't remember the details but if you "search" on this site under "breast cancer" for that subject you might find it.
Posts.Title: reconstruction

Posts.Content: On 4/10/2008 hanagirl wrote: I had DCIS with surgery followed by radiation almost 5 years ago.  My breast has formed into a very painful and hard mass and my doctors have found no more cancer but say very little about how it happened or what can be done.  It cannot be pressed on at all and basically hurts most of the time.  Has anyone else had this happen to them and what if anything was done for you?  Apparently it is not a common occurrence.  Would appreciate hearing from you... kelley Hardness of breast tissue to some degree after radiation is not uncommon.  Have you continued stretching since your operation?  I'm told I have to continue that for the rest of my life since having radiation.  Try to stretch very gently to help loosen up the fibrosis.  Myofascial release helps too but you'd have to consult with a PT and see if that would help you since you can't stand to be touched.  My lymphedema therapist is now treating some clients with this problem with a low level laser approved for lymphedema treatment.  It is working and giving these women relief from the pain.  These lasers have been in use in Australia for years but were only approved by the FDA in December 2006 so hospitals in the US are just starting to acquire them.  Check with your hospital's rehab, PT or lymphedema treatment center to see if they've heard of this or have one yet.  Hope this helps.
Posts.Title: Hard breast following radiation

Posts.Content: On 4/13/2008 hanagirl wrote: Thank you so very much for your message!  This was the first time I had ever used this type of site to share my problem.  I do not have lymphedema, just a rock hard right breast with extreme sensitivity.  It is also very tight to stretch my arm but have always worked with stretching and I use it in my job so its a bother but not like the 'cement' like breast.  After reading more of the message board I see a few other women have experienced this but not alot.  Seems not much can be done.  I appreciate your time in getting back to me.  Many thanks and good health. Hi Hanagirl, I wasn't clear enough in my message about the laser treatment.  You do not have to have lymphedema for the laser to help with the condition you're experiencing from radiation treatment.  To find a therapist with the laser you will need to be looking for a lymphedema therapist.  It could help, as could myofascial release.  For that kind of massage therapy try to find a body worker who's worked with cancer patients--that's what I did.  My range of motion has improved a lot and I no longer have the pain in the chest area that I did (I can hug easier and wear a seatbelt much more comfortably.)  Hope I've been a bit clearer for you.
Posts.Title: Hard breast following radiation

Posts.Content: Neulasta caused me to feel like I'd been run over by a Mack truck, then a Hummer and then a pick-up truck.  Couldn't stand to be touched I hurt so much.  Finally decided I'd rather go in for 5-7 days in a row and get Neupogen shots (precursor to Neulasta) and the side effects weren't as bad.  You might also look into accupuncture for pain relief.
Posts.Title: Neulasta

Posts.Content: I believe the fear can leave.  You'll need to tell it that it's not wanted and you're not allowing it to be in you anymore (I also tell this to the cancer--I was stage 3A).  If you've never tried postive affirmations or visual imagery or some sort of meditation, I would highly recommend them.  Prayer can help too, if you believe in it.  Every time I lay down at night I pray, "Thank you God for healing me."  Expect and believe that all your check-ups will show you are still healthy.  This all takes practice but it's worth the time. Blessings and peace to you.
Posts.Title: I'm in remission, but my side effects still scare me sometimes.

Posts.Content: I'm wondering if you've been checked for lymphedema?  Cellulitis can be a serious problem for lymphedema patients.  Getting the lymphedema under control could help reduce/eliminate the cellulitis.  I echo Tre's advice.  I see a naturopathic dr. and she's helped me w/the side effects of the Arimidex.  I also have had intuitive touch healings, reiki, & cranio-sacral massage therapy---they've all helped---some physically, some emotionally & mentally. Blessings and good luck!  You'll get through this with your determination.
Posts.Title: Recurring Cellulitis

Posts.Content: On 8/30/2009 chazz wrote: i was complaining about a sour breast, then while i was in the bath i found a lump just below my nipple and it really scared me , the first thing what came into my head was breast cancer, im 14 and i dont no what to do? is this breast cancer? Hi Chazz, Hope you meant that your breast is sore/hurting and not sour/smelly.  I know when I was young and it was around the time for my period I would get a really sore spot on one breast.  Sore or itchy nipples can also be a part of the menstrual cycle.  But I agree with the other post, get it checked out for peace of mind.
Posts.Title: i have a lump, sour and really red nipples.

Posts.Content: On 1/8/2009 bluefootedbooby wrote: Mastectomy or lumpectomy? I 'm a 60 year old with DCIS. I can't decide which to have.  Ihave very fair and sensitive skin prone to sunburn. Would radiation be harder on me than someone with less sensitive skin? Thanks in advance for any input. Hi Bluefoot (love the name!) Statistics show lumpectomy to be as effective as mastectomy.  I would assume a lumpectomy is easier to recover from (I had a modified radical mastectomy)  You might ask how large a chunk they intend to take (have them draw on yr. breast so you have a visual), then you can decide whether that's OK w/you or you want a mastectomy and reconstruction.  It really boils down to what you feel is best for you. As far as radiation goes, I'm a brunette and burned badly.  My blonde Irish friend said she only got as bad as a bad sunburn.  Go figure!  Just be sure to use the lotions they recommend (or if they don't then look for the ones w/aloe in them). Good luck w/your treatment.
